data.headline: Weekend Brief: Markets rally on AI strength but face renewed tariff and trade war fears as Trump pivots to global duties and volatility rises ahead of key data and Nvidia earnings
bullets: S&P 500 gained 0.7% Friday and 1.1% for the week, while Nasdaq outperformed with a 1.9% weekly gain led by Meta, Nvidia, and Amazon on AI spending optimism
Trump’s push for a maximum 15% global tariff under Section 122 revives trade war and deficit concerns, impacting import- and trade-sensitive sectors including tech, semis, autos, and retailers
Hopes emerge for $100B–$175B in business refunds, but uncertainty rises for multinationals and inflation-sensitive stocks
Asian markets mixed as Hong Kong’s Hang Seng weakens post-Lunar New Year and mainland China edges higher amid US-Iran tensions and tariff confusion
European markets end modestly higher, with rare-earth supply deals boosting US materials and oil’s Iran-linked rise supporting energy stocks like XOM and CVX
Private-credit jitters pressure Blue Owl, Ares, and Blackstone, while major banks remain resilient despite renewed scrutiny after JPMorgan’s Trump debanking admission
Bitcoin’s “$1T identity crisis” weighs on COIN and MSTR, adding to sector volatility
Traders eye a quiet US corporate weekend before key Monday pre-market earnings (DPZ, D, FRPT), S&P Global Flash PMIs, factory orders, and Fed Governor Waller’s speech

Nvidia’s upcoming earnings, ongoing Big Tech policy scrutiny, and potential further tariff details around the State of the Union keep volatility elevated, with prediction markets pricing higher S&P 500 correction risk into 2026
